content: I'm starting to really like these, how about a part3?

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: J'ai trouvé que le puzzle présentait de nombreux concepts innovants et intéressants. Il permet de façon ludique d'aborder et apprendre les règles de chaîne de calcul. Comme mentionné avant moi j'aime beaucoup l'approche pour l'utilisation des priorités des opérations qui amène à l'analyser des fonctions trigonométriques et logarithmiques telles qu'elles sont écrites en cours de mathématiques.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Writing a solution in lua it's OK for me

The statement is a little clumsy and can seem not very coherent, for example, the language for the formula contains only + - ^ , but the author give results with - or /

Some remarks after a first reading of the statement :

1/ "Story" in place of "Stroy" I think ;-)

2/ Evaluate the correctness of the derivation with only one point is perhaps very optimistic. (In fact I have the same remark for first part too)
Perhaps have a list of points to evaluate instead only one

3/ In puzzle we avoid using Unicode char (cp>126) in input or output to be friendly to some language where unicode char management could be painfull (and in fact you don't user greek symbol in your test ^^).
And in another hand, in your test, some variable name contains underscore 
So "the var would be some letter (or ASCII letter) followed by letters, numbers or underscore' for me.

4/ the description of expression language is a little clumsy, but I have no idea to make it clearer without a formal description :(

5/ Beware of the rounding ! without reading your provided solution I don't know which rounding your use. Just be precise : is it a truncation ? rounding to nearest ?

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: This puzzle has many interesting concepts. It's educational to learn the calculus chain rules. This puzzle takes parsing PEMDAS to a whole new level with needing to parse trig/log functions as they are written in math class. And it's a good progression from Part 1.

Goal section
* Suggest to change "In her homework" to "When doing her homework".
* Can "Nth" be deleted in "Nth partial derivative"?

Input section
* Please change "line1:" to "<<Line 1:>>". Similarly for "line2:" and "line3:".

Constraints section
* Please change "line2" as "Line 2".

Thanks.

Nice puzzle!

I think there's a problem with the the assumption that power ^ is left associative instead of the standard right associative: https://math.stackexchange.com/a/1633800/128852

i.e. 2^3^2 should be parsed as 2^(3^2) but the sample solution reads it the other way around (2^3)^2

A test case for this:

x*(2^3^2)
x
x 42

You could clarify that Louise's homework has nonstandard notation. (But that recursive parsing nontrivial.)

Nice point ! Thanks !
I fixed that problem.
thanks!

same logic about recursive.
in my opinion, Hard one should related to advance algorithm which I am not good at. :)))
thanks for feedback!
is it possible to help approve it? thanks ~

done accordingly, thanks

Thanks for reviewing!
For 1, 3 and 5, I modified accordingly.
2/one point checker could be optimistic, but one must be really lucky to pass all tests with a wrong answer. ;))
3/the "Unicode" is a residual from previous modifications, once I had some chinese / greek / japanese chars as vars, but all deleted when many alerted me about Unicode.
Thanks a lot !
Merci beaucoup !

Hi thanks!
any idea of what could be added for a part3?
Ha, not really, I wouldn't have thought this one was solvable.
is it possible to help approve it? thanks ~
is it possible to help approve it? thanks ~

Awesome, now my binary op parsing--which is all right-associate--works great :)
It's great to not have - or / as ops.

Validator 6 caught a bug in my code: I need to fix my generic (x^y)' derivative rule. It fails on i.e. partial x of (ln x)^5
= ((ln(x) ^ 5.0) * ((0 * ln(ln(x))) + ((1 * (x ^ -1)) * (5.0 * (ln(x) ^ -1)))))
= ((ln(x) ^ 5.0) * ((x ^ -1) * (5.0 * (ln(x) ^ -1))))

Evaluating that at x=1 doesn't work because (0^5 * 0^-1) explodes... I might make my simplifier able to combine powers that are multiplied, or I can just hardcode the (x^a)' rule :)

It is not my intention to have a special test for the x^5*x^-1 situation, but it is fun to know that. :)

Test7 is the same as Validator6, so if a solution passes test7 , it won't have trouble.
Hi CarlWalsh, is it possible to help approve it? thanks ~
